abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Industrial
            Rehabilitation and Promotion Project for Guinea was
            unsatisfactory. The project achieved some of its objectives,
            its impact on institutional development was only partially
            successful, sustainability is uncertain at this time, and
            the performance of the Bank was satisfactory while the
            Borrower's was unsatisfactory. Several lessons can be
            learned from this project. First, in designing projects of
            this type, more attention should be given to analyzing the
            strengths and weaknesses of target institutions, including
            their ability to manage efficiently the different components
            of the project. Second, local project management capacity
            must be fostered in order to ensure that
            institution-building takes place. Third, commercial banks
            should be pressured to be more rigorous in the supervision
            of their sub-borrowers as well as their collection
            practices. Finally, in retrospect, given the open-ended
            reorientation that the project assumed following the
            reforms, it would have been more efficient to undertake a
            full mid-term review or a complete reappraisal of project
            objectives and respond to new challenges brought about by
            the far-reaching economic reforms.
